result.title: Objective
result.description: To mainstream biodiversity conservation into Uzbekistans oil-and-gas policies and operations by demonstrating this in the Ustyurt Plateau.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Amount of funds invested by oil-and-gas companies in biodiversity conservation, which contributes to reduced habitat destruction and fragmentation, maintenance of ecosystem services and connectivity, and reversals in loss of native vegetation.

baseline.comment: Zero of investments by oil-and-gas companies in biodiversity conservation.

target.comment:
By the project end total investments of oil-and-gas sector into preservation of biodiversity reached USD 2 million.
New Target Level at end of project -
-By the project end total investments of oil and gas sector into preservation of biodiversity reached USD 1 million.

actual.comment:
US$ 233,400
The expenses of the UzKorGasChemical company (Surgil project) as of June 30, 2015 on biodiversity restoration equal to USD 233,400: out of which $168,900 during this reporting period.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Square of the territory of Uzbek steppe ecosystem over which the oil-and-gas operations integrate biodiversity conservation

baseline.comment: Absence of land area over which oil-and-gas operations integrate biodiversity conservation considerations.

target.comment:
As result of project implementation land area over which oil-and-gas operations integrate biodiversity conservation considerations increased to 1.7 mln. hectares.
New Target Level at end of project -
-As result of project implementation land area over which oil-and-gas operations integrate biodiversity conservation considerations increased to 1.3 million hectares

actual.comment:
625.5 ha
The company UzKorGazChemical (Surgil project) conducted biodiversity restoration on 625,5 hectares, out which 427,5 ha during the reporting period.
620 ha out of 625.5 ha is under the natural vegetation of (Haloxylon aphyllum) saxaul.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Enabling policy, legislative, and institutional environment for mainstreaming in oil-and-gas sector

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 1. Number of amended laws and policy documents are analysed, complemented by biodiversity conservation requirements and submitted to the Government for approval.

baseline.comment: No amended Laws that facilitate the incorporation of biodiversity conservation requirements into planning and implementation of oil-and-gas operations (to be tracked in more detail through the SO 2 Tracking Tool).

target.comment: At least 7 Laws (On Environmental Protection, On Environmental Examination, On Protected Natural Territories, On Protection and Use of Flora, On Protection and Use of Fauna, On State Cadastres, Land Code) reviewed to incorporate biodiversity conservation and monitoring issues. Amendments with regulations on the avoid-reduce-remedy-offset principles in extractive industries, including development of norms and methodology for determining indirect negative impacts on flora and fauna, prepared to above mentioned Laws. After approval by stakeholders proposed amendments to at least 7 Laws submitted to the Government for review and subsequent approval (accordingly to existing procedures).

actual.comment: In 2013, the Project finalized the draft law of the Republic of Uzbekistan On introducing changes and additions to some legislative acts of the Republic of Uzbekistan on the conservation of biodiversity and agreed the document with 13 ministries and agencies. The draft law provides changes and additions to 12 legislative acts. The Executing Agency (SCNP) officially submitted the draft law to the Cabinet of Ministries. In 2015, the Executing Agency also referred the draft law to the Legislative Chamber of the Oliy Majlis for inclusion in the work schedule of the Committee for ecology and environmental protection for 2015

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 2. Availability of Amendments on biodiversity conservation requirements made to State Ecological Examination process and EIA screening instruments and submitted to the Goskompriroda for approval.

baseline.comment: No amended state mandated ecological screening processes and instruments for monitoring biodiversity impacts of oil-and-gas projects.

target.comment: The current status of State Ecological Examination process and Environmental Impact Assessment reviewed. Amendments with norms incorporating a thorough check of biodiversity impacts of proposed oil-and-gas projects prepared. After approval by stakeholders proposed amendments on biodiversity conservation requirements to State Ecological Examination process and EIA screening instruments submitted to the Goskompriroda for review and subsequent approval (accordingly to existing procedures).

actual.comment: The Project drew up a number of documents on improvement of state environmental examination, namely: the draft resolution of the Cabinet of Ministers of the Republic of Uzbekistan On further improvement of environmental expertise, Regulations on environmental impact assessment of planned or ongoing economic and other activities, List of information and data for environmental impact assessment, Regulations on environmental audit, the Explanatory note and the Concept of these documents. All the document were submitted to the State Committee for Nature Protection for consideration and approval.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 3. Availability of mapping of (i) lands that should be off-limits to exploration and drilling, (ii) lands where extraction projects are allowed, but should have mitigation measures, and (iii) lands where a restoration or offset scheme is needed for inclusion to the Oil-and-gas Sector Development Plan for 2013-2017.allowed, but should have mitigation measures, and lands where a restoration or offset scheme is needed

baseline.comment: No mapping of (i) lands that should be off-limits to exploration and drilling, (ii) lands where extraction projects are allowed, but should have mitigation measures, and (iii) lands where a restoration or offset scheme is needed.

target.comment: The State Programme of Development of the Oil-and-Gas Industry (2007-2012) and its future extensions reviewed. A field survey (BD and GIS) to collect necessary information for development of the map conducted. Economic analysis of the program of regional development conducted. Map of (i) lands that should be off-limits to exploration and drilling, (ii) lands where extraction projects are allowed, but should have mitigation measures, and (iii) lands where a restoration or offset scheme prepared, discussed and submitted to Government for inclusion into new State Programme of Development of the Oil-and-Gas Industry (2013-2017).

actual.comment: The Project finalized the Map of zones of the Ustyurt Plateau. In zone 1, every activity of oil-and-gas sector is prohibited, in zone 2, development of oil and gas fields is not recommended, in zone 3, development of oil and gas fields is permitted when the measures on mitigating adverse impacts on biodiversity are implemented. The Map will be used as an instrument of EIA of oil-and-gas sector on the Ustyurt Plateau. The Map is ready for submission to the Implementing Agency of the Project (SCNP) for approval.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: 4. Number of Officers from Uzbekneftegaz, Inspectors from State Committee for Nature Protection, Environmental Officers of leading oil-and-gas companies are trained in principles and practical approaches for avoid-reduce-remedy-offset approaches to oil-and-gas operations.of government and industry staff trained in principles and practical approaches for avoid-reduce-remedy-offset approaches to oil-and-gas operations.

baseline.comment: Zero (0) government and industry staff trained in principles and practical approaches for avoid-reduce-remedy-offset approaches to oil-and-gas operations.

target.comment: 3 Officers from Uzbekneftegaz, 25 Inspectors from State Committee for Nature Protection, 7 Environmental Officers of leading oil-and-gas companies trained in principles and practical approaches for avoid-reduce-remedy-offset approaches to oil-and-gas operations. The finalized/corrected training modules submitted for inclusion into curriculum of special educational institutions.

actual.comment: The Project developed teaching modules on the basis of manual on biodiversity conservation. The Project organized trainings for staff of oil-and-gas companies and state environmental organizations. Four trainings for officers of oil and gas companies and state environmental organizations in Nukus and four trainings in Tashkent were held in 2014-2015. 114 officers, 17 of whom are women, were trained: 62 specialists of SCNP, including 2 women, and 52 specialists of oil-and-gas companies, including 15 women.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Demonstrating biodiversity mainstreaming technologies on the ground in the Ustyurt Plateau

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
5. No decrease populations of indicator species in the project territory.
New Indicator -
Number of Ellobius
talpinus colonies at the sites where project implemented joint measures with Fauna and Flora International and other partners

baseline.comment:
Baseline population figures will be determined once the biodiversity inventories are completed in the demonstration area by year 2 of the project.
New Baseline: 8 colonies per 1 ha

target.comment: No decrease over baseline values observed.

actual.comment: The Project carried out restoration of vegetative cover on a pilot plot of 50 ha on the territory of the Ustyurt Gas Chemical Complex. In May 2015, the seeds came up, but during the first year after planting the vegetative cover will be weak and cannot be settled by herbivorous rodents such as Ellobius talpinus. The first year vegetative cover is insufficient to feed these animals.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description:
6. % of square of the area which earlier adversely affected by habitat destruction and fragmentation along pipelines, has in place measures aimed at regeneration and recovery of native vegetation.
New Indicator -
- Square of the area (in ha) which earlier adversely affected by habitat destruction and fragmentation has in place measures aimed at regeneration and recovery of native vegetation.

baseline.comment:
Baseline to be documented in year 1.
New Baseline- 0 ha

target.comment: At least half of this area has in place measures aimed at regeneration and recovery of native vegetation

actual.comment: In 2014, the Project analyzed the destruction of vegetative cover on two construction sites Surgil project and Shakhpakhty field. A pilot plot of 50 ha was selected on each of two sites. Zarubezhneftegaz GDP Central Asia operating on Shakhpakhty gas field refused to cooperate in restoration activities. The Uz-Kor Gas Chemical Company agreed to cooperate. In November 2014, seeds of native plant species were planted on a plot of 50 ha (the plot selected earlier was replaced by another). In May 2015, from 4 to 6 shoots per 1 m2 were detected on the pilot area of recovery.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description:
7. % of decrease of poaching incidents in project area compared with baseline levels.
New Indicator -
-Number of inspectors to decrease in poaching incidents on Saiga antelope

baseline.comment:
Baseline to be documented in year 1.
New Baseline-
-3 inspectors per 7 million ha, e.g. 1 inspector per 2.3 million ha

target.comment: Poaching incidents decreased by 10% to baseline.

actual.comment: The Project is finalizing the process of reorganization of the Saigachy preserve. The Project is finalizing its activities on reorganization of the Saigachy reserve into a complex landscape reserve. It remains to get an approval of the draft resolution of the Cabinet of Ministries on the reorganization from three ministries. The draft resolution provides that the guarding staff will consist of 10 specialists on the territory of 735,200 ha that is 1 biodiversity inspector per 73,520 ha.

indicator.title: Output Indicator

actual.comment:
1.1 38 government officials, including 7 women representatives of State Committee for Nature Protection, State Customs Committee, Ministry of Higher and Secondary Specialized Education, Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Ministry of Finance, Ministry of Justice and others were involved in regional and national level activities on implementation of nationally adopted HCFC phase-out strategy, and contributed to its effective implementation Evidence: Reports by government officials and international experts.
1.2 Officials of the Government of the Republic of Uzbekistan attended in networking with non-Art 5 and other Art 5 countries. Namely, 6 (including 2 women) high-level officials from Uzbekistan have participated in International Conferences and Workshops related to the International cooperation on Montreal Protocol, including (i) HCFC Phase-out regional Project Board Meeting in Istanbul; (ii) in the resumed Thirty-Sixth Meeting of the Open-Ended Working Group of the Parties to the Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer and in the Twenty-Seventh Meeting of the Parties to the Montreal Protocol in Dubai; (iii) in the Thematic meeting on HPMP, Minsk and (iv) study tour on ODS destruction and application free-ODS technologies in China. Evidence: Reports by government officials
2.1 Five (5) sets of refrigeration recovery and recycling equipment (portable stations for recovering and recycling of refrigerants, basic refrigerant identifiers, manifolds with accessories, infrared (non-contact) digital thermometers, 60 pounds cylinders for refrigerants, electronic weighting scales, vacuum pumps, set of technicians safety equipment and leak detectors) and one set of refrigeration recovery/recycling/reclaim equipment (EcoCycle Aurora II, manifolds with accessories, 100 pounds cylinders for refrigerants, electronic weighting scales, vacuum pumps, set of technicians safety equipment and leak detectors) procured and to be handed over to six national HCFC recover

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description:
1.1.1. # of IDUs reached through trust points and community outreach
1.1.2. # of SW reached with HIV prevention services
1.1.3. # of MSM reached with HIV prevention services
1.1.4. # of new young people reached by peer education
1.1.5. # of new STI treatment courses provided in friendly cabinets
2.2.1.1. # of eligible HIV positive people receiving ARV treatment
2.2.1.2. # of OI treatment courses delivered
2.2.1.1. # of eligible HIV positive people receiving ARV treatment
2.2.1.2. # of new Opportunistic Infections (OI) treatment courses delivered
2.2.2. # of PLHIV and their family members benefiting from psycho social support
2.2.3. # of health care staff trained in provider initiated testing and counseling
2.2.4.1. # of staff trained in PMTCT
2.2.4.2. # and percentage of HIV positive pregnant women who have received ARV prophylaxis to reduce MTCT in accordance with nationally approved treatment protocol
2.2.4.3. # and % of infants born to HIV positive mothers who received ART prophylaxis
3.3.1. National plan of actions for YY 2012-2016 in place
3.3.2. # of epidemiologists trained on infection control
3.3.3. # of care standards adopted by the government by Jan 2014
4.1.1.1# of meetings of NGO Network held
4.1.1.2 # of initiatives that are launched by NGO Network
4.1.2.1. # of trained journalist on HIV, stigma, gender aspects, and prevention of discrimination issues
4.1.2.2. # of high level events on stigma and discrimination and HIV as social issue conducted
5.1.1.1. # of oblast s of Uzbekistan where SS conducted
5.1.1.2. # of oblasts covered by electronic databases developed that are effectively functioning for monitoring of prevention, treatment programs and drug forecasting in the country
6.1.1.1 Number of medical staff trained in infection control
6.1.1.2. % of health facilities that meet the basic service capacity standards in infection control (WHO/GF top 10 indicator)
6.1.2. # of lab specialists trained in Quality Control
6.1.

baseline.comment:
1.1.1. 16108 IDUs reached through trust points and community outreach
1.1.2. 6932 SW reached with HIV prevention services
1.1.3. 1180 MSM reached with HIV prevention services
1.1.4. 31703 young people reached by peer education
1.1.5. 7824 STI treatment courses provided in friendly cabinets
2.2.1.1. 3832 eligible HIV positive people receiving ARV treatment
2.2.1.2. 7405 OI treatment courses delivered
2.2.2. 3552 PLHIV and their family members benefiting from psycho social support
2.2.3. Medical staff requiring additional qualification to provide counseling and testing
2.2.4.1 Medical staff requiring additional training on PMTCT
2.2.4.2. 485/678 71.5% pregnant women who have received ARV prophylaxis to reduce MTCT
2.2.4.3. 481/520 91.5% of infants born to HIV positive mothers who received ART prophylaxis
3.3.1. National action plan on HIV/AIDS expired in 2011 (YY2006-2011)
3.3.2. insufficient level of knowledge on infection control among country epidemiologists (300 epidem. trained in infection control in 2011)
3.3.3. Absence of care standards on health services provision to HIV positive people
4.1.1.No network of NGOs that will enable civil society to actively participate in the process of combating HIV/AIDS
4.1.2.1. High level of stigma and discrimination against PLHIV in the society as well as among opinion makers.
4.1.2.2. Lack of commitment among policy makers and service providers at different levels to reduce stigma and discrimination against PLHIV and MARPS
5.1.1.1. Sentinel Surveillance conducted in the Y 2009
5.1.1.2. No electronic database for monitoring of HIV prevention, treatment programs and drug forecasting in the country
6.1.1.1 Medical staff requiring additional knowledge in infection control
6.1.1.2. 66.7% of health facilities meet the basic service capacity standards in infection control
6.1.2. Lab staff requiring knowledge in quality control
6.1.3.1. weak voluntary blood donation programs/systems
6.1.3.2. 82%

target.comment: 1.1.1. 28,000 IDUs reached through trust points and community outreach 1.1.2. 10,000 SW reached with HIV prevention services 1.1.3. 1,400 MSM reached with HIV prevention services 1.1.4. 35,000 new young people reached by peer education 1.1.5. 10,000 of new STI treatment courses provided in friendly cabinets 2.2.1.1. 8000 of eligible HIV positive people receiving ARV treatment 2.2.2. 4000 of PLHIV and their family members benefiting from psycho social support 2.2.3. 50 of health care staff trained in provider initiated testing and counseling 2.2.4.2. 1200/1250 and 96% of HIV positive pregnant women who have received ARV prophylaxis to reduce MTCT in accordance with nationally approved treatment protocol 2.2.4.3. 95% of infants born to HIV positive mothers who received ART prophylaxis; 2.2.5. 60% of adults and children newly enrolled in HIV care receiving isoniazid preventive therapy 5.1.1.2. 30 specialists trained on ARV forecasting and stock management tools

actual.comment: 1.1.1. 24,552 IDUs reached through trust points and community outreach 1.1.2. 11,842 SW reached with HIV prevention services 1.1.3. 1,491 MSM reached with HIV prevention services 1.1.4. 45,105 new young people reached by peer education 1.1.5. 9,332 of new STI treatment courses provided in friendly cabinets 2.2.1.1. 8325 of eligible HIV positive people receiving ARV treatment 2.2.2. 7406 of PLHIV and their family members benefiting from psycho social support 2.2.3. 60 of health care staff trained in provider initiated testing and counseling 2.2.4.2. 393/396 and 99.2% of HIV positive pregnant women who have received ARV prophylaxis to reduce MTCT in accordance with nationally approved treatment protocol 2.2.4.3. 543/549 and 98.9% of infants born to HIV positive mothers who received ART prophylaxis; 2.2.5. 0% of adults and children newly enrolled in HIV care receiving isoniazid preventive therapy 5.1.1.2. 30 specialists trained on ARV forecasting and stock management tools

target.comment: 1. 29,000 IDUs reached through trust points and community outreach 2. 12,600 SW reached with HIV prevention services 3. 1,500 MSM reached with HIV prevention services 4. 13250 of MARPs (IDUs, SWs, MSM) tested and counseled for HIV and who received test results 5. 10,000 of new STI treatment courses provided in friendly cabinets 6. 8325 of eligible HIV positive people receiving ARV treatment 7. 65% of adults and children newly enrolled in HIV care receiving isoniazid preventive therapy 8. 8000 of PLHIV and their family members benefiting from psycho social support 9. 582/600 and 97% of HIV positive pregnant women who have received ARV prophylaxis to reduce MTCT in accordance with nationally approved treatment protocol 10. 570/600 and 95% of infants born to HIV positive mothers who received ART prophylaxis 11. 75% of health facilities that meet the basic service capacity standards (in infection control) 12. 17/17 and 0.0% of health facilities dispensing antiretroviral therapy that have experienced a stock-out of at least one required antiretroviral drug in the last 12 months

actual.comment:
Reporting for the period January 1 June 30, 2015 1. 25,157 IDUs reached through trust points and community outreach 2. 11,417 SW reached with HIV prevention services 3. 1420 MSM reached with HIV prevention services 4. 9833 of MARPs (IDUs, SWs, MSM) tested and counseled for HIV and who received test results 5. 6122 of new STI treatment courses provided in friendly cabinets 6. 7852 of eligible HIV positive people receiving ARV treatment 8. 5329 of PLHIV and their family members benefiting from psycho social support 9. 197/201 and 98% of HIV positive pregnant women who have received ARV prophylaxis to reduce MTCT in accordance with nationally approved treatment protocol 10. 255/262 and 97.3% of infants born to HIV positive mothers who received ART prophylaxis
Reporting for the period July 1 December 31, 2015 1. 25,395 IDUs reached through trust points and community outreach 2. 12,279 SW reached with HIV prevention services 3. 1492 MSM reached with HIV prevention services 4. 10,098 of MARPs (IDUs, SWs, MSM) tested and counseled for HIV and who received test results 5. 10368 of new STI treatment courses provided in friendly cabinets 6. 8575 of eligible HIV positive people receiving ARV treatment 8. 8833 of PLHIV and their family members benefiting from psycho social support 9. 316/318 and 99,4% of HIV positive pregnant women who have received ARV prophylaxis to reduce MTCT in accordance with nationally approved treatment protocol 10. 480/490 and 98% of infants born to HIV positive mothers who received ART prophylaxis

iati-activity.title: Integrated Landscape Management (LAND)
iati-activity.description: The project is designed to support the improved, more sustainable and more resilient land use management of non- irrigated arid desert, steppe and mountain landscapes of Uzbekistan.

iati-activity.title: Integrated Landscape Managemen
iati-activity.description: Reducing pressures on natural resources from competing land use in non-irrigated arid mountain, semi-desert and desert landscapes of Uzbekistan

result.title: Objective
result.description: To promote integrated management of rangeland and forests at the landscape level (focus on non-irrigated, arid mountain, semi-desert, and desert landscapes) to reduce pressures on natural resources from competing land uses and improve the socio-economic stability of communities.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of hectares of pastures, forest and rain-fed arable land in two target districts that are under improved management.

baseline.comment: Zero

target.comment:
11,000 hectares of improved forestries.
26,000 hectares of improved pastures.
2,000 hectares improved rainfed lands.
Long-term goal: at the replication rate of 2%, improved management will be introduced on 600,000 hectares of forests, 4 million hectares of pastures and 150,000 hectares of rainfed lands in 10 years

actual.comment: Currently areas under improved management include 18 ha of forest, 50 ha of pasture, 20 ha of rain-fed lands.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Promising best practices on sustainable rangeland and forestry management and INRM planning up-scaled in target districts of Uzbekistan.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Improvement or maintenance of vegetative cover in pilot sites in target districts

target.comment:
Maintenance in vegetative cover or improvement in cover over baseline by:
8% for pastureland;
6% for forestry; and
6% for rain-fed areas

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Area of pasture classified as degraded in project sites

baseline.comment: 280,000 ha (95,000 ha Zaamin, 185,000 ha Karakul)

target.comment: 254,000 ha or less by year 5 (84,000 or less in Zaamin; 170,000 or less in Karakul)

actual.comment: Pasture degradation has reduced due to implementation of the project actions in first year: by 30 ha in Zamin and by 20 ha in Karakul

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Area of pasture used by dekhans (households) under collaborative management (pasture user groups)

baseline.comment: Zero

target.comment: 300 hectares of pastures are jointly managed by two PUGs

actual.comment: N/A. Data will be obtained at the end of this year and reported in the next PIR.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Number of dekhans with formal legal rights (and obligations) for areas used as pasture

baseline.comment: Zero

target.comment: At least 600 hectares will be managed based on contracts with shirkats by the 5th year of project implementation.

actual.comment: N/A. Data will be obtained at the end of the third year

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Area of forest planted or managed through state and community collaborative mechanisms (JFM, community forests, collaborative moving sand fixation)

baseline.comment: Zero

target.comment: Not less than 100 ha by year 5 (60 Zamin, 40 Karakul)

actual.comment: During the first year the project together with forestry entities and local communities of both pilot areas created two forest nurseries: 3 ha in Zamin and 2.5 ha in Karakul.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Humus content of rain-fed arable land in plough layer

baseline.comment: Average 16.7 t/ha

target.comment: Improvement in humus content of 100 ha rain-fed arable in Zaamin district (16.7 t/ha) by year 5

actual.comment: N/A. Data will be obtained at the end of the third year.

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description: Local small businesses involved in production or application of appropriate technologies

baseline.comment: None

target.comment: 5 businesses involved in production/services related to appropriate technology for reducing fuel wood demand, cost effective well pumping or renewable energy production by year 5

actual.comment: Business plans and necessary formal documents prepared for a vine garden and a shop for processing medical plants. Equipment, fencing and seed materials are purchased. Full assessment will be provided at the end of this year.

indicator.title: Indicator 8
indicator.description: Number of livestock wells rehabilitated and adequately maintained in project sites

baseline.comment: Not more than 10

target.comment: 10 wells rebuilt by the 5th year of project implementation

actual.comment: N/A. Data will be obtained at the end of this year.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: An enabling cross-sector environment and in-country capacity (at system, institutional and individual levels) for applying integrated landscape management in arid mountain, semi-desert and desert areas of Uzbekistan

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: National pasture use strategic policy/plan incorporating long term integrated sustainable pasture use objectives

baseline.comment: No mid/long term strategic development policy for pasture use in Uzbekistan

target.comment: A mid/long term strategic policy for sustainable pasture use which provides a basis for legal and institutional reform

actual.comment: Concept for national strategy on land use improvement developed and concept of national program in the field of pasture and forestry area management drafted.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: An up-to-date national forestry programme / plan supported by government that incorporates long term integrated sustainable use objectives

baseline.comment: National forestry programme prepared but lacks key components and full government commitment for implementation.

target.comment: An updated national forestry programme/plan approved by government and has an allocated budget by year 5

actual.comment: Concept for national strategy on land use improvement developed and concept of national program in the field of forestry area management drafted.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: A strategic policy/plan on rain-fed agriculture that incorporates long term integrated sustainable use objectives

baseline.comment: No such strategic plan

target.comment: A strategic plan for the long term development of rain-fed arable agriculture and role in overall agricultural system by year 5

actual.comment: Concept for national strategy on land use improvement developed and concept of national program in the field of rain fed area management drafted.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Inter-ministerial mechanism for ensuring coordination of land use policies operating effectively

baseline.comment: Mechanism exists in principle

target.comment: Inter-ministerial Coordinating Council has a clear mandate and method of operation to ensure coordination of different land use sectors by year 4

actual.comment: Progress on this indicator will be reporting in the next PIR.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Pasture legislation and tenure arrangements allow more effective pasture use and fully recognize household/dekhan pasture users

baseline.comment: No specific pasture use legislation, other legislation such as Land Code inadequate

target.comment: Either a Pasture Law for Uzbekistan or adequate revisions to Land Code and other relevant legislation and normative documents completed by year 5

actual.comment: No progress this reporting period. Some activities will start at the end of this year and will be reported in the next PIR.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: National and regional training institutions producing graduates with sound understanding of integrated land use concepts and approaches

baseline.comment: Current national and regional training institutions have outdated courses which poorly address sustainable land use issues, particularly of non-irrigated landscapes

target.comment: At least 1 training institution at national level and 1 at regional level have strengthened curriculum that addresses sustainable land use planning, including in non-irrigated areas by year 5.

actual.comment: No progress this reporting period. Some activities will start at the end of this year and will be reported in the next PIR.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1.Number of mechanisms/procedures improved to enable business environment: registering property; construction permits, connecting to electricity, and obtaining licenses and permits 2.Number of reform proposals that provide innovative solutions to improve business climate are developed in participatory manner (with at least 30% of women participation) 3. A platform for online interactive services for business is available and effectively functioning 4. Number of jobs/income opportunities piloted in rural areas as a demonstration of successful inclusive business models. 5. Comprehensive sector based resources mobilization approaches (road map) to implement inclusive business models is available in CCI

baseline.comment: 1.Existing procedures related to business environment are too bureaucratic and time-consuming 2. Insufficient engagement of stakeholders in business related policy formulation processes. 3. There is no on-line interactive mechanism for business, which would integrate multiple state agencies providing timely, cost-efficient and qualitative public services. 4. Rural population, especially women and youth are in particular disadvantage in finding decent employment and income opportunities. 5. Absence of comprehensive Resources Mobilization Guideline to implement inclusive business models

target.comment: 1. The procedure for registering property for businesses is revised and improved jointly with stakeholders. 2.Draft Government resolution with an action plan on further improvement of business registration service developed, vetted with relevant agencies and submitted to the Government. 3. n/a 4.{preparatory phase for creating jobs/ income opportunities in pilot rural areas} 5. n/a

actual.comment: 1. Through comprehensive consultations and negotiations with State Geodesy and Land Cadaster Committee, State architecture and construction Committee and Ministry of justice key issues complicating property rights registration procedures have been identified by UNDP including the needs for universal set of data, applicants needs in property rights registration when applying for land plot allocation and for construction permits. A set of recommendations on improving property rights registration application, interagency data exchange and implementing this service on businessinfo.uz portal for entrepreneurs have been elaborated. Recommendations on simplifying notary registration of real estate transactions between legal entities have been also elaborated. As a result, they were included in the draft of the resolution of the Cabinet of Ministers. Notable ones include: granting Chamber of Commerce and Industry of Uzbekistan additional power to monitor an activity of government agencies on issuing licenses, permit documents and provision other public service to entrepreneurs; publishing on Uzbekistan open web portal (www.my.gov.uz) an exhausted list of all documents required by government agencies while providing public services to entrepreneurs; setting provision prohibiting a claim by government agencies from an applicant the documents which are available and can be provided by other government agencies, including certificates of tax debts or debts on utility bills, copies of the constituent documents of a business entity, copies of licenses and permit documents. Evidence: Resolution of Government by #377 dated December 31, 2014. 2. Draft Resolution of the President On measures to improve business registration system has been elaborated and endorsed by all relevant ministries and state departments and Cabinet of Ministers and submitted to the Presidents office. Key recommendations was to eliminate all barriers for business registration. Following transformations in

target.comment: 1.Three essential procedures of obtaining construction permits, connecting to electricity, and obtaining licenses and permits are revised and improved jointly with stakeholders. 2. At least 2 new reform proposals on further improvement of business climate in the country developed in participation with stakeholders 30% of whom are women through online public review mechanisms 3. Streamlined business registration system is developed and includes comprehensive e-databases; guidelines for users and instructional sets for the staff. At least 10 new jobs created for rural women by implementing 2 pilot small inclusive business initiatives in partnership with private sector organizations. Recommendations for scaling up of inclusive business models discussed and shared with stakeholders 5. n/a
